description.narrative: Equitable access to quality education for all, by strengthening education CSOs in Tanzania through capacity building, advocacy, research and networking.

TENMET is a civil society umbrella organization that networks CSOs in the education sector with the aim of a)Improved capacity of member CSOs 2)Advocacy for equitable access to quality education 3)Research on gender-based violence 4)Networking with national and international education actors 5)Buildcapacity to accomplish its mandate

TENMET är ett nätverk av civilsamhälleorganisationer som arbetar för att förbättra tillgången till kvalitativ utbildning för alla. TENMET gör detta genom att stärka medlemsorganisationernas kapacitet att påverka beslutsfatttare och medvetandegöra allmänheten om vikten av kvalitativ utbidlning för alla och behovet av att avlägsna alla hinder, såväl strukturella som kulturella, för att nå målet. TENMET bidriver tillämpad forskning för att underbygga påverkansarbetet och influera policyer. Nätverksarbete, samverkan och dialog med nyckelaktörer, inklusive ministerier, är också några av TENMETs arbetsmetoder.

participating-org.narrative: TENMET-Sida/Tanzania Education Network Mtandao Wa Elimu Tanzania

tag.narrative: 4.1 - By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.
4.1 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla flickor och pojkar fullbordar avgiftsfri och likvärdig grundskole- och gymnasieutbildning av god kvalitet som leder till relevanta och ändamålsenliga kunskaper.

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: The government of Tanzania through the Ministry of education (MOEST) ultimately issued a circular to reverse the government proposal which if continued would have placed teacher education in a wrong government structure and hence compromising quality of education in Tanzania. The circular number 5 of 2016 nullified the decision that placed Teacher Education under National Council for Technical Education (NACTE). The government issued a new circular as a result of TENMET public outcry that requires the MOEST’s Directorate of Teacher Education to be responsible for the management of Teacher Education and the National Examination Council of Tanzania (NECTA) to be responsible for examination and certification. The study to analysed the magnitude of impact of the placement of Teacher Education under NACTE was also presented to MOEST by TENMET when such controversial discussion was happening. It is assessed that this intervention was one of the powerful study carried out by TENMET Secretariat independently and delivered a remarkable result. All this echoes for the importance of technical know how in an effort to influence government on technical education matters. On the other hand,TENMET seemed to have successfully advocated for inclusion of nutritional issues as part of school development plan in three districts in namely Uyui, Nzega and Tabora municipality in Tabora region. Through advocacy work, member CSOs who were part of the advocacy team, improved their knowledge on the importance of nutritional interventions in schools. One of the unexpected result from TENMET work on nutrition promotion was the government commitment to support income generating initiatives in schools. For example, the government pledged to support constructing business frames/shops for Chemchem primary school through Tabora regional engineer’s technical support unit. In Tanzania, the 2016 Global Week of Action on Education (GAWE) theme ‘Financing Education! Education Rights now! was commemorated. The education week was marked from the 16th to 20th May, 2016 in Kilwa, Lindi Region where 25 CSOs were able to mobilise 17.4m Tanzania shillings to support educational activities that would improve pupil's learning environment. It is about 1,200 people including community members, government officials, teachers, school heads, pupils and students attended GAWE launch and climax in Kilwa District in Lindi Region. It is reported that different Media houses made coverage during the week to spread the GAWE messages in the county thus amplifying GAWE message that is 'Education Right Now'. GAWE is not just an event but for TENMET it is a continuous platforms with set targets and indicators to ensure access and quality in education is achieved. Embassy of Sweden considers GAWE approach as becoming relatively sustainable compared to the past as it has moved from event to action based. TEN/MET reported some few media engagements in this fiscal year. TENMET used television and radio to advocate for an inclusive learning environment. TENMET visited Bagamoyo where a 'case primary' school was identified for advocacy campaign. Different video clips were developed after that and aired to portray challenges that girls and children with disability face in every day school life. It is reported that eventually the advocacy campaign got viral in several social media platforms. It is not substantiated if such wide spread of the campaign message was a contributing factor for government to initiate discussion on development of inclusive education policy but TENMET claims that the television and radio spots seemed to have provoked discussion amongst different stakeholders including the government. TEN/MET is committed to quality service to its members. To achieve this goal, the network enhances the capacity of its board and Secretariat staff for them to be able to contribute to an efficient, effective vibrant CSOs in Tanzania. In this fiscal year a number capacity development activities were conducted including Monitoring and evaluation, financial management and child protection.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
